awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: COLLAB: Autonomy as a Service
awd_abstract_narration:
How can one deploy teams of autonomous robots over long periods of time in such a way that they can be recruited and tasked by operators to perform a wide variety of tasks? Examples of such tasks include the environmental monitoring tasks encountered in biological conservation applications or in precision agriculture. This project will address this issue by letting the autonomous robots be available to the user in an on-demand manner through a novel 'Autonomy as a service' framework. To realize this idea, new tools will be developed for (i) describing the tasks in a way that can be understood by the robots, (ii) ensuring that the robots stay safe while executing the tasks, and (iii) methods for the robots to learn and improve over time in combination with the ability to assess their performance. The broader impact from the project will include implications for environmental monitoring, outreach programs for increasing STEM participation, and an integration of the research findings into the curriculum at the three participating institutions (Georgia Tech, BU, and MIT). 

In detail, the three main research themes are: (i) From Specification to Execution: The users must be able to recruit and task the robots with new missions, which calls for formally correct ways of going from high-level specifications, formulated as Linear Temporal Logic formulae, to coordinated control programs for the robots to execute. (ii) Resilient Autonomy: When delivering a system that can be commanded to perform tasks over long periods of time, the first concern must be to preserve the integrity of the system itself, i.e., basic functionality must be ensured even as the robot team is recruited to perform a particular set of tasks. This project will achieve this through the use of composable barrier certificates that ensure the forward invariance of the safe set, i.e., if the robots start safe, they will stay safe. (iii) Trajectory Based Learning from Massive Data Sets: The agent team must be able to assess the performance of whatever it is that they are monitoring. In this project, this will be achieved through models that can be effectively learned from massive data sets through novel tools for data compression and representation.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, which was a collaboration between Georgia Tech, MIT, and BU, we defined and developed the concept of “Autonomy as a Service”. This refers to the ability of a group of autonomous robots, deployed in an environment over a sustained period of time, to be recruited and commanded to perform a wide variety of tasks in response to user specifications, while ensuring that the basic integrity of the system is preserved. The particular focus was on persistent monitoring tasks.

Central to autonomy as a service is the ability to recruit and task robots with new missions, which calls for formally correct ways of going from high-level specifications to coordinated control programs for the robots to execute. In this project, we proposed a set of specification languages based on temporal logics, traditionally used in formal methods in computer science. The specifications given in these languages are composable, in the sense that they can be directly combined with other specifications to support increasingly complex missions.

When delivering a system that can be commanded to perform tasks over long periods of time, the first concern must be to preserve the integrity of the system itself, i.e., basic functionality must be ensured even as the robot team is recruited to perform a particular set of tasks. During this project, we defined a notion of resilient autonomy, and encoded it formally using forward invariance properties (if the system starts safe, it stays safe) through constraints obtained from control barrier certificates.

We have also defined a data-driven, machine learning approach to infer environmental properties from massive data sets. Such properties were expressed in the same formal language as the specifications described above, which allowed for seamless composition of missions with properties learnt from data. To this end, we first developed a method to effectively and sparsely represent data to make it amenable to learning. We then developed a machine learning approach to infer temporal logic properties from temporal sequences of such sparse representations.

The algorithms developed in this project have been successfully tested in robotic experimental platforms at GaTech, MIT, and BU. The project also enabled a rich set of educational and outreach activities, including the MIT’s Beaver Works Summer Institute, worldwide use of the Robotarium at GaTech, and the Technology Innovation Scholars Program (TISP) at BU.
